item.title: New website, thanks to Quarto
item.dc:creator: Matthew Andreotta
item.description:
Today, I upload a new version of my academic website. All thanks to the magic of ✨ Quarto ✨.

For the unaware, Quarto is an open-source publishing system. I first started using Quarto to seamlessly use Python and R in the same markdown document. But Quarto can do so much more: books, presentations, and of course, websites.

Overall, the process of building rather painless. Partly because Quarto has comprehensive documentation and partly because I followed the footsteps of those before me. For readers interested in building a website with Quarto, here are the websites I found useful:

Foundations

  • Creating a website | Quarto documentation
  • Creating your personal website using Quarto, by Sam Csik | Blog post
  • We don’t talk about Quarto, by Alison Hill | Blog post
  • Quarto for the curious, by Tom Mock | Slides

Tips and tricks

  • Quarto for an Academic Website by Drew Dimmery | Blog post
  • Porting a distill blog to quarto, by Danielle Navarro | Blog post
  • A Quarto tip a day keeps the docs away, by Mine Çetinkaya-Rundel | Blog post | Twitter

Visuals

  • Some emojis supported by Quarto | Github gist
  • Bootstrap icons supported by Quarto | Icons
  • Font awesome extension for Quarto | Extension | Icons
  • Unsplash, a database of photos for free use | Photos | License
  • Pexels, another database of photos for free use | Photos | License
  • Bootswatch, free out-of-the-box colour schemes for your Quarto documents | Palettes
